abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Primary Education
            Development Project for Bangladesh were as follows: outcome
            was satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory;
            and Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: in a sector-wide approach (SWAP),
            the leadership of development partners requires a mix of
            "hard skills", "soft skills", and
            flexibility. The World Bank proved to play an important role
            in supporting fiduciary processes and participating in the
            technical dialogue. While there is agreement that ownership
            is an important determinant of success, the concept of
            ownership is often seen as a dichotomous process either
            there is ownership or not. The World Bank expressed repeated
            concerns about the government's ownership of the
            program, for example, the use of consultants to prepare the
            macro plan and concerns that the government initially raised
            about a SWAP. No sector is an island and it is important for
            sector programs to coordinate with efforts to strengthen
            public administration and governance. A SWAP is an
            evolutionary process that requires flexibility and
            adaptation to succeed. With support, governments can
            transform monitoring and evaluation (M and E) systems from a
            pro forma system of collecting data to a powerful tool for
            monitoring and decision making.
